prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC2110: nuclear kinematics
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Trace nuclear molecular gas kinematics via CO J:2-1 and CS J:5-4 (dense gas). Spectral (5--10km/s) and spatial (0.5 km/s) resolutions used to match our in-hand ionized and stellar kinematic data (Gemini-GMOS IFU). The two additional spws are used in TDM mode (highest sensitivity) to cover a Hydrogen recombination line and continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our kinematic science goals will use the CO and CS lines. The spws covering these two lines are thus set to spectal line mode (intrinsic resolution ~1.5km/s). Velocity features as small as 5 to 10km/s are seen in our optical IFU (Gemini-GMOS) and we thus target a similar spectral resoultion with ALMA (using spectral smoothing 8, to get intrinsic resolutions of ~6km/s resolution). This will be further smoothed as neccessary in post processing in order to increase signal to noise. Total line widths in the proposed galaxies are <= 450km/s, so that the full line will easily fit into the 1.8GHz baseband. The two remaining windows target a Hydrogen recombination line (expected to be weak) and continuum, and are thus set to TDM mode.

Our Gemini-GMOS Integral Field Unit observations of the proposed galaxies have ~0.6arcsec resolution and a FOV of about 5"x5". Ionized gas streaming and inflow/outflow signatures are seen in these data. We thus here request 0.5arcsec resolution observations to match the resolution of the optical IFU data. The CO J:2-1 observations proposed here have sufficient FOV to cover the Gemini-GMOS IFU studied region. The continuum LAS could be larger than 4arcsec and we could thus lose some extended structure in the requested observations: however this does not effect the key science goal. Molecular gas emission is expected across the full FOV, however, given that we will use a spectral resolution of 6 to 10km/s we do not expect to have structures larger than 4arcsec at any given velocity channel.

We are interested in sub-kpc scale molecular gas kinematics (see below) to match our in-hand ionized gas and stellar kinematics from Gemini-GMOS IFU. Since the target galaxies do not have exceptionally strong (compared to eg., NGC1097, NGC1068) single dish CO fluxes, we target the CO emission rather than dense gas tracers like HNC or HCN. We thus target the CO J:2-1 transition to balance between tracing dense gas and not requiring good weather conditions. The CS J:5-4 (dense gas tracer) is also observable in our setup. We would like to trace kinematics at resolutions of 0.5" spatial and 10km/s spectral (see below). None of the galaxies proposed have previous CO interferometric maps in the literature. We thus use single dish fluxes to estimate the expected fluxes for the proposed galaxies. We use the results of the NUGA survey of nearby AGNs with the PdBI to guide us. NUGA observed 12 nearby AGNs with 0.5--2" spatial resolution, 5--10km/s spectral resolution, and an rms sensitivity of ~2--4 mJy in CO J:1-0 and ~8mJy in CO J:2-1 (see e.g., van der Laan 2011 for specific example). These parameters were sufficient to extract meaningful kinematics for their galaxies.
The validity of the estimations are confirmed with our previous ALMA observations (with the same setup requested here) of the 4 galaxies in our sample with delivered ALMA data (Cycle 1 carried over to Cycle 2). For these four galaxies, the delivered ALMA data all detect the CO line at sufficient SNR to extract kinematics at spatial and velocitiy resolutions sufficiently high to address our science goals. For our proposed spatial and spectral resolution (and the worst case scenario that the CO flux is uniformly distributed) we expect 4--9 times lower fluxes per beam as compared to NUGA. Also, the single dish fluxes of our proposed sample are lower than that of the typical NUGA galaxy by factor 2--5. We therefore request 10 times better sensitivity as compared to NUGA CO J:2-1 maps, or 0.7mJy per 10km/s channel. This is achievable with ALMA in roughly one hour total time per galaxy.
The single dish CO data for NGC2110 are as follows: CO J:2-1: I_CO = 1.9 K km/s and deltaV=320km/s with JCMT (23" beam; Rigopoulou+1997) CO J:1-0: I_CO = 0.45 K km/s and deltaV=355km/s with the NRAO 12m (55" beam; Maiolino+1997) This is thus the weakest CO flux of our sample, but is still well detectable with ALMA.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC3081: nuclear kinematics
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Trace nuclear molecular gas kinematics via CO J:2-1 and CS J:5-4 (dense gas). Spectral (5--10km/s) and spatial (0.5 km/s) resolutions used to match our in-hand ionized and stellar kinematic data (Gemini-GMOS IFU). The two additional spws are used in TDM mode (highest sensitivity) to cover a Hydrogen recombination line and continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our kinematic science goals will use the CO and CS lines. The spws covering these two lines are thus set to spectal line mode (intrinsic resolution ~1.5km/s). Velocity features as small as 5 to 10km/s are seen in our optical IFU (Gemini-GMOS) and we thus target a similar spectral resoultion with ALMA (using spectral smoothing 8, to get intrinsic resolutions of ~6km/s resolution). This will be further smoothed as neccessary in post processing in order to increase signal to noise. Total line widths in the proposed galaxies are <= 450km/s, so that the full line will easily fit into the 1.8GHz baseband. The two remaining windows target a Hydrogen recombination line (expected to be weak) and continuum, and are thus set to TDM mode.

Our Gemini-GMOS Integral Field Unit observations of the proposed galaxies have ~0.6arcsec resolution and a FOV of about 5"x5". Ionized gas streaming and inflow/outflow signatures are seen in these data. We thus here request 0.5arcsec resolution observations to match the resolution of the optical IFU data. The CO J:2-1 observations proposed here have sufficient FOV to cover the Gemini-GMOS IFU studied region. The continuum LAS could be larger than 4arcsec and we could thus lose some extended structure in the requested observations: however this does not effect the key science goal. Molecular gas emission is expected across the full FOV, however, given that we will use a spectral resolution of 6 to 10km/s we do not expect to have structures larger than 4arcsec at any given velocity channel.

We are interested in sub-kpc scale molecular gas kinematics (see below) to match our in-hand ionized gas and stellar kinematics from Gemini-GMOS IFU. Since the target galaxies do not have exceptionally strong (compared to eg., NGC1097, NGC1068) single dish CO fluxes, we target the CO emission rather than dense gas tracers like HNC or HCN. We thus target the CO J:2-1 transition to balance between tracing dense gas and not requiring good weather conditions. The CS J:5-4 (dense gas tracer) is also observable in our setup. We would like to trace kinematics at resolutions of 0.5" spatial and 10km/s spectral (see below). None of the galaxies proposed have previous CO interferometric maps in the literature. We thus use single dish fluxes to estimate the expected fluxes for the proposed galaxies. We use the results of the NUGA survey of nearby AGNs with the PdBI to guide us. NUGA observed 12 nearby AGNs with 0.5--2" spatial resolution, 5--10km/s spectral resolution, and an rms sensitivity of ~2--4 mJy in CO J:1-0 and ~8mJy in CO J:2-1 (see e.g., van der Laan 2011 for specific example). These parameters were sufficient to extract meaningful kinematics for their galaxies. Note that their sample has single dish CO J:2-1 fluxes of I_CO ~ 10 to 30 K km/s.
The validity of the estimations are confirmed with our previous ALMA observations (with the same setup requested here) of the 4 galaxies in our sample with delivered ALMA data (Cycle 1 carried over to Cycle 2). For these four galaxies, the delivered ALMA data all detect the CO line at sufficient SNR to extract kinematics at spatial and velocitiy resolutions sufficiently high to address our science goals. For our proposed spatial and spectral resolution (and the worst case scenario that the CO flux is uniformly distributed) we expect 4--9 times lower fluxes per beam as compared to NUGA. Also, the single dish fluxes of our proposed sample are lower than that of the typical NUGA galaxy by factor 2--5. We therefore request 10 times better sensitivity as compared to NUGA CO J:2-1 maps, or 0.7mJy per 10km/s channel. This is achievable with ALMA in roughly one hour total time per galaxy.
The single dish CO data for NGC3081 are as follows: CO J:2-1: I_CO = 4.3 K km/s and deltaV= 300 km/s with JCMT (23" beam; Petitpas+04)

Since the target galaxies do not have exceptionally strong (compared to eg., NGC1097, NGC1068) single dish CO fluxes, we target the CO emission rather than dense gas tracers like HNC or HCN. We thus target the CO J:2-1 transition to balance between tracing dense gas and not requiring good weather conditions. The CS J:5-4 (dense gas tracer) is also observable in our setup. We therefore request 10 times better sensitivity as compared to NUGA CO J:2-1 maps, or 0.7mJy per 10km/s channel. This is achievable with ALMA in roughly one hour total time per galaxy.
The single dish CO data for Mrk1066 are as follows: CO J:2-1: I_CO = 23.7 K km/s and deltaV=150km/s with IRAM 30m (12" beam; Krugel+1990) CO J:1-0: I_CO = 11.2 K km/s and deltaV=150km/s with the IRAM 30m (22" beam; Krugel+1990)

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: In this continuation project, we propose CO kinematic observtions of six nearby galaxies, chosen to show streaming inflows/outflows and/or bright (IR) molecular disks in our 0.5arcsec resolution optical and IR Integral Field observations. The 0.5arcsec images of the proposed galaxies (plus the four galaxies already observed by us and a handful of others in the ALMA archive) will allow us to: a) map the CO distribution, morphology and kinematics on kpc to 50pc scales, for comparison with stellar features (e.g. bars and disks) and kinematics b) search for signatures of molecular gas inflows and outflows and compare the corresponding molecular and ionized gas mass rates using models of circular rotation and stellar kinematics as references. c) compare mass inflow/outflow rates with nuclear star formation rates and black hole accretion rates and thus constrain the inflow timescales.
